item.title: üéÅA Special Gift...and 60 more Mental Models!
item.description:
Hello again Mental Models Lovers!

To celebrate reaching 100 subscribers after only 5 weeks, I'm sharing a special gift.

I like to read. A lot. Across a broad range of topics. Whenever I find something worth reading or that I‚Äôd like to refer to in the future, I save it. I‚Äôve done this for many years. What‚Äôs resulted is a long-list of high-quality, curated resources (800+) across my areas of interest and areas I‚Äôve sought answers to in the past (and continue to seek answers to).

Having a project increases our motivation to learn.

Sick of paywalls?

Meet 12ft ladder. It lets you bypass any paywall.

The idea is simple: news sites don‚Äôt show the Google crawler a paywall so they can appear in search results.

12ft grabs this cached, un-paywalled version of the page and shows you.

item.title: 15 Of The Best Decision-Making Mental Models I've Found
item.description:
15 Of The Best Decision-Making Mental Models I've Found

1) The Inside-Outside View

We have a natural tendency to favour the inside view‚Äîour own independent solution to a problem that incorporates all of our hidden biases.

To make better decisions, we should favour the outside view‚Äîone that incorporates the best available data.

2) Ladder of Inference

Describes the thinking process we go through‚Äîoften subconsciously‚Äîto get from a fact to a decision or action.

item.title: 15 Timeless Lessons On Investing And Building Wealth
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 15 timeless lessons on investing and building wealth

Lesson 1:

‚ÄúThe most consistent way to get rich is to grow your income and invest in income-producing assets.

This doesn‚Äôt imply that you can ignore spending.

Everyone should do a periodic review of their spending to ensure it isn‚Äôt wasteful.

But there is no need to cut your lattes.‚Äù

Calendar-Priority Alignment

1. ‚ÄúWhat are your priorities?‚Äù

2. ‚ÄúIf I look at your calendar, would it be obvious to me that those are your priorities?‚Äù

Hack: Use your Calendar as your to-do list so that your highest priority to-dos actually get done.

2 short frameworks to improve conversations

Wait, What?

A method to avoid jumping to conclusions or making snap judgements.

When someone presents an idea, opinion, or a belief, ask "Wait, What?"

It reminds you to slow down.

item.title: 31 Things I've Learned In 25 Years of Living
item.description:
1. Ask for what you want in an assertive manner, just make sure you have the runs on the board. Know your worth. 

2. Be unreasonably interested in other people when you are meeting and getting to know them. Ask questions, be attentive and engaged. Just make sure it doesn‚Äôt become an interrogation. 

3. Don‚Äôt take things personally, unless of course someone has deliberately set out to get you. There are a myriad of reasons why people can act in a way that negatively affects you. It‚Äôs not always a personal attack. In most cases, what‚Äôs happening in someone else‚Äôs life is far more important to them and will determine their actions

6 techniques to learn faster

Deliberate Practice

Regular practice involves mindless repetitions and staying in your comfort zone.

Deliberate practice involves focused attention on the micro-components of a skill, specific goals, and feedback on performance from an expert.

item.description:
Welcome to the 1,374(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

Take Sleep Seriously

Human beings are the only species that deliberately deprive themselves of sleep.

But emerging from research in the last 10 years is an unmistakable message:

Sleep is the single most effective thing we can do to reset our brain and body health each day.

item.title: A Few Of My Favourite Parables
item.description:
To Change The World

When I was a young man, I wanted to change the world.

I found it was difficult to change the world, so I tried to change my nation.

When I found I couldn‚Äôt change the nation, I began to focus on my town. I couldn‚Äôt change the town and as an older man, I tried to change my family.

Now, as an old man, I realize the only thing I can change is myself, and suddenly I realize that if long ago I had changed myself, I could have made an impact on my family. My family and I could have made an impact on our town. Their impact could have changed the nation and I could indeed have changed the world.

item.title: A Few Special Updates And 10 Mental Models To Maximize Your Cognitive Potential
item.description:

I really appreciate your support over the course of the year, and am excited to announce a few improvements to the Newsletter (with a few more exciting ones in the works...so stay tuned!).

item.title: A Simple Framework To 10x Your Network
item.description:
A simple framework to 10x your network

Help This Person

Every time you encounter another person, think: "How can I help this person?"

It's not altruistic.

Nothing else can so quickly accelerate your career and improve your quality of life.

Being helpful is the best form of "self-promotion" there is.

When you see someone you'd rather not spend time talking to, think "help this person."

Instead of giving short answers and trying to end the conversation abruptly, genuinely ask how they are and what they're working on.

item.title: A System For Learning Intelligently
item.description:
A system for learning intelligently

Learning how to learn is one of life‚Äôs most important skills.

Here‚Äôs how you can do it intelligently.

1. Learning Selection

Have you ever started learning something only to stop a few days or weeks later?

This can happen for lots of reasons, but often it's bad learning selection.

Selecting what you learn and when you learn it is crucial to maintaining motivation to finish it.

Here are some questions to make sure you're choosing well:

Learning how to learn is one of life‚Äôs most important skills.

Here‚Äôs how you can do it intelligently.

1/ Learning Selection

Have you ever started learning something only to stop a few days or weeks later?

item.title: Advice you most need to hear
item.description:
Life advice is useful when it resonates emotionally and logically. It‚Äôs useful when it changes your behaviour. It is true that not all life advice is useful over time. What‚Äôs useful now may not be useful in 10 years. What was useful 5 years ago, isn‚Äôt useful now.

‚Äç

For this reason, periodically assessing the ‚Äòadvice you most need to hear‚Äô and keeping that front of mind is pivotal to becoming the highest version of yourself. If you are already performing in alignment with a given set of advice, you don‚Äôt need to remind yourself of specific advice.

item.title: Agency is your ability to shape circumstances
item.description:
Agency is your ability to shape circumstances instead of being shaped by them.

Most people live their entire lives as spectators. They watch others build companies, create movements, and change history. They attribute success to luck, timing, or privilege. This is a comforting illusion that protects their ego.

The truth is simpler and harder to accept: agency is a choice.

Every billionaire, world-changer, and history-maker made this choice. They decided they wouldn't accept the world as given. They would bend reality instead. This isn't mystical ‚Äî it's mechanical. You either believe your actions matter or you don't.

item.title: Agenda-Setting Theory, The Ergodic Switch, Convexity, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 10 mental models that will make you smarter

Agenda-Setting Theory

Mainstream media sets the agenda of public discourse.

The more attention the media gives to certain issues, the more likely the public is to consider them important.

Don‚Äôt pay blind attention to what‚Äôs on the ‚Äúagenda‚Äù and forget what‚Äôs not being said.

You can then:

item.title: Career things I'd tell my younger self
item.description:
Brand names (Stripe, Anthropic, Goldman Sachs, McKinsey) are optional, but they do imply positive traits that people will take you seriously for. If you don‚Äôt get a brand name, you can still imply your capabilities in a permissionless way through the internet. Create content. Create apps. Build things people want. Apprentice under someone impressive by sending them a cold email.

‚Äç

Work insanely hard in your 20‚Äôs. Weekends are a social construct popularised by Henry Ford in the early 20th century to encourage people to travel more (so they would use his cars). Do with this information what you will.‚Äç

item.title: Consensus-Contrarian Matrix, Curse of Knowledge, Perfect Solution Fallacy & More
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the A Players newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 10 mental models that will make you smarter

Consensus-Contrarian Matrix

In order to produce outsized returns in any given area, you have to both bet against the convention and be right.

‚ÄùYou can‚Äôt take the same actions as everyone else and expect to outperform.‚Äù

‚ÄîHoward Marks

Curse of Knowledge

Once we know something, we assume everyone else knows it, too.

item.title: Decomplication, Via Negativa, Speed Matters, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 7 mental models you can use to actually be productive (instead of just reading about mental models that make you ‚Äúfeel‚Äù productive)

Decomplication

We‚Äôve been led to believe that our everyday problems‚Äîweight loss, productivity, saving money‚Äîrequire complex solutions.

This is called ‚Äòartificial complexity.‚Äô

Decomplication is the process of boiling problems down to their simplest form.

item.title: Deep Work, Hofstadter's Law, Elon's Law, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 11 of the most powerful frameworks and principles for productivity

Deep Work

Deep work is single-tasking, limiting your context switching and distractions in your immediate working environment.

Shallow work is logistical-style tasks, often performed while distracted.

h/t Cal Newport

Hofstadter's Law

Projects always take longer than expected, even when you take into account Hofstadter‚Äôs Law.

item.title: Don't compare your 1st iteration to someone else's 100th
item.description:
The grandstand's metal seat sears through my shorts as I sit alone, sweat beading on my forehead, my pulse racing in sync with the ripples in the pool below. Serbia‚Äôs July sun beats down mercilessly, but it's not just the heat that's making my palms clammy.

‚Äç

It's 2012. I'm 15, and it's my first time overseas without a parent. I'm with my club water polo team in Belgrade for a training camp before the National Championships. We‚Äôre at Partizan, arguably the world‚Äôs most famous club, known for its long list of Olympians.  I‚Äôm excited to test myself against the best. I rate myself. How good could they be? I started playing water polo 4 years ago. Between swimming, gym, and actual sessions, I‚Äôve been training up to 13 times a week. It‚Äôs all I do and think about.

item.title: Eisenhower Decision Matrix, ICE Framework, Regret Minimization Framework, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 10 of the best prioritization mental models I've found

Eisenhower Decision Matrix

Best for day-to-day decisions.

Prioritize tasks by urgency and importance and decide which tasks should be delegated or not done at all.

‚ÄùWhat is important is seldom urgent, and what is urgent is seldom important.‚Äù

‚ÄîDwight Eisenhower

ICE Framework

Best for short-term prioritization decisions (weeks or months).

item.description: I‚Äôve tried to apply the mental models you share and it‚Äôs helped me in my life. I‚Äôm sharing this newsletter with several friends because I‚Äôm sure others will find it valuable as well.

item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 12 mental models you can use daily to improve your life

Good and Bad Procrastination

Good procrastination is avoiding work with 0 chance of being mentioned in your obituary‚Äîlike errands.

‚ÄùUnless you're working on the biggest things you could be, you're type-B procrastinating, no matter how much you're getting done.‚Äù

h/t @paulg

item.title: Great leaders don't just manage people
item.description: The chlorine-scented air stings my nostrils as I catch my breath, my arms draped over the pool's edge, water lapping gently against my chest. The sun glints off the surface, but it's not the light that's making me squint ‚Äì it's the anticipation of what's about to unfold. It's April 2013. I'm training with the Western Australian State School Boys team ahead of the National Championships in June. It's our first session, and my coach, Andrew, is splitting the squad into two teams for a practice game.

‚Ä¢ What makes you happy

‚Ä¢ What‚Äôs smart ‚Äî meaning long-term good for you

‚Ä¢ What‚Äôs useful to others‚Äù

item.title: How can some people get so lucky in life?
item.description:
We often think that luck is about being in the right place at the right time. But the surest way in life to find luck is much easier. What follows is the story of how the most powerful woman in startups creates 'luck' out of thin air.

‚Äç

Ann Miura-Ko (@annimaniac) has been labelled the most powerful woman in start-ups by Forbes. She is:

  • A co-founding partner of Floodgate Venture Capital
  • An early investor and board member in Lyft
  • A lecturer in entrepreneurship at Stanford
  • And a world-class debater

Ann‚Äôs parents came to America seeking opportunity having grown up in post-WW2 Japan. They had almost no money, spoke very little English, and had no support system when they arrived. What they did have was a steely grit and determination to make a life in America. Her father worked intensely to receive a PhD in mechanical and aerospace engineering.

item.title: How the world might look in 30 years
item.description:
‚ÄçBy 2030

‚Äç

AI

  • AI will surpass human capabilities in all healthcare diagnostic tasks
  • AI will be smarter than a Nobel Prize winner across biology, programming, math, engineering, writing and have access to all the interfaces available to a human working virtually, including text, audio, video, mouse and keyboard control, and internet access
  • AI-powered personal assistants became capable of generating entire new movies
  • AI will automate AI research, compressing decades of progress into single years
  • AI will displace up to 30 percent of our workforce resulting in 400 to 800 million job losses

‚Äç

item.title: How To Be More Effective In 2023? These Will Help
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the A Players newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: How to be more effective in 2023? These will help

Decomplication

We‚Äôve been led to believe that our everyday problems‚Äîweight loss, productivity, saving money‚Äîrequire complex solutions.

This is called ‚Äòartificial complexity.‚Äô

Decomplication is the process of boiling problems down to their simplest form.

h/t @nateliason

Via Negativa

When we have a problem, our natural instinct is to add a new habit or buy a solution.

item.title: How to choose the highest leverage activities to work on
item.description:
To increase your leverage, ask yourself before any activity:

  • How could I complete this task in a fraction of the time to the same standard? (decrease time cost)
  • What is the expected (confidence x ROI) impact of this task? (increase value)
  • What else could I be doing that's higher leverage? (opportunity cost)

To identify your highest leverage task, ask:

If I could only do one thing for the rest of the week that would have the greatest impact, what would it be?

item.title: How to find your life's work
item.description:
Arguably, the best thing Steve Jobs ever said:

‚Äç

‚Äç‚ÄúThe only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work. And the only way to do great work is to love what you do. If you haven‚Äôt found it yet, keep looking. Don‚Äôt settle. As with all matters of the heart, you‚Äôll know when you find it.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚ÄçThe problem? Most of us don‚Äôt know where to look...

item.title: How To Master Uncomfortable Conversations
item.description:
Fast Summary

  • Difficult conversations are a necessary evil both in and out of the workplace. We can‚Äôt skip them, so instead, we must learn to navigate them positively.
  • To tackle uncomfortable conversations, we need to first use an integrative mindset, which allows us to adapt and remain neutral when faced with difficulty.
  • Acknowledging our own discomforts, managing our emotions, and adjusting our communication approach is key to handling difficult conversations with ease.
  • Next time you have a difficult conversation, focus on your goals and intentions.
  • When we master difficult conversations, we command respect from our peers, gain confidence, and, most importantly, get what we want.

Throughout my early career, I struggled to engage in difficult conversations, especially those that stretched my comfort zone, involved crucial feedback, or addressed poor performance either from myself or others.

item.title: How To Master Uncomfortable Conversations
item.description:
Fast Summary

  • Difficult conversations are a necessary evil both in and out of the workplace. We can‚Äôt skip them, so instead, we must learn to navigate them positively.

  • To tackle uncomfortable conversations, we need to first use an integrative mindset, which allows us to adapt and remain neutral when faced with difficulty.

  • Acknowledging our own discomforts, managing our emotions, and adjusting our communication approach is key to handling difficult conversations with ease.

item.title: How to read anyone‚Äôs character instantly
item.description:
(1) Observe Their Partner
Who people choose to partner with says more than anything they say. It tells us more about their desires, assumptions, and needs than anything else. It indicates their priorities and values, as well as what they think of themselves.

(2) Observe How They Handle No
Rejection is a big part of life. Those who take "No" poorly usually have an overinflated sense of entitlement. The world owes no one anything. Those who accept and live by this are people you can share bad news with easily.

item.title: How To Set Practical & Achievable Life Goals
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: How to set practical & achievable life & business goals

In 1983, Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) were introduced to the world by Andy Grove‚Äîformer CEO of Intel.

But, it was only in 1999 when John Doerr‚Äîwho worked for Andy Grove‚Äîintroduced the framework to Larry Page and Sergey Brin (Founders of Google) that it really took off.

item.title: How you do anything is how you do everything
item.description:
My lungs feel like they're on fire as I collapse onto the page-white sand, each breath a desperate gasp that tastes of salt and exhaustion. The Indian Ocean stretches before me, a vast blue expanse that seems to mock my spent body, while the merciless sun beats down above.

‚Äç

It's 2012, and I've just completed another gruelling run-swim-run as a surf life saving cadet. As a year 10 student, I'm part of a group of fifty cadets who've chosen surf life saving as our extra-curricular activity. Every Friday afternoon, we face the same challenge: an 800-meter sand run, followed by a 500-meter swim, and another 400-meter sand run to finish.

item.title: I had a conversation with a billionaire
item.description:
3 months ago, I had a short conversation with a billionaire. I asked for their book recommendations, but I got a lesson I‚Äôll remember for the rest of my life. They told me that they don‚Äôt give advice or mentorship. That they‚Äôve never received any value from it.

‚Äç

They shared the view that other people‚Äôs advice is often from their own unique experience and is often wrong or at least much less valuable when applied to your own circumstance. They said that instead of seeking advice they had ‚Äúread a lot and studied and experimented and failed and learned and then finally succeeded.‚Äù

item.title: If you‚Äôre not curious, you‚Äôll never be great
item.description:
The elevator doors slide shut, sealing me in with my dreams and doubts. It's 2019, and I'm ascending to the 30th floor of Goldman Sachs, my heart racing faster than the lift itself. At 21, with the dust of European cobblestones and South American trails still clinging to my shoes following a gap year, I've landed what many consider the holy grail of finance jobs.

‚Äç

Despite my excitement, I'm acutely aware of how little I know. I create an extensive list of resources to learn: financial modelling, valuation techniques, industry primers ‚Äì you name it. Over the next few months, I immerse myself in the material alongside my full-time job. I'm learning rapidly, and although it's not always visible, I'm improving quickly.

item.title: Increasing returns to focus
item.description:
Many people advocate for building ‚ÄúRange‚Äù in your career, but this is wrong. People who have built phenomenal careers with outsized returns do not do this. Instead, they do one thing at incredible depth for an astoundingly long time. In the next few decades, those who do this stand to profit even more than they have in the past. We‚Äôre entering the era of ‚Äúincreasing returns to focus.‚Äù

‚Äç

Why?

‚Äç

item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the A Players newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 10 incredible free websites

Information is beautiful

Information is beautiful distills data, information, and knowledge into beautiful, useful graphics & diagrams.

The site is dedicated to helping you make clearer, more informed decisions about the world.

https://informationisbeautiful.net

Kialo

Kialo allows you to see arguments on both sides of any debate in the world.

item.title: Jootsing, Worm's Eye View, The Easterlin Paradox, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 8 mental models that will make you smarter

Jootsing

An extreme version of thinking outside the box that involves:

1) First gaining deep knowledge of the system and its rules

2) Then stepping outside to find something that subverts its rules

3) And finally, using your findings to make something new and creative

Leave Me Alone, ToffeeShare, Octopus.do, Examine & More

item.title: Life is short and fleeting
item.description: The antiseptic smell of the hospital corridor hit me as I rushed towards my father's room, my heart pounding in my chest. It‚Äôs September 9, 2009, and just moments ago, I had been sitting quietly in the back row of my school chapel during a weekly assembly. I‚Äôm 12, an idealistic kid with a keen grasp of life‚Äôs possibilities. A never-ending sense of time. And a playful demeanor with a curiosity for life‚Äôs playground. But, for the last 6 months, my Dad has been in a stoic battle with cancer. And it‚Äôs finally getting the better of him. It‚Äôs spread to his liver. And it‚Äôs terminal.

item.title: Life Lessons & Hacks
Luiz P.
item.description: I have my normal inbox. I have my best newsletter‚Äôs inbox. And I have my outliers inbox‚ÄîFaster Than Normal.

Some highlights for this week include:

  • Meehl Pattern

This week we covered 100 mental models (concepts and biases) across psychology and general thinking.

As you read through, I would love if you could consider the following questions (please shoot me a response if you‚Äôd like to give feedback on either of them!):

  • Was the level of explanation sufficient to understand the concept?
  • Would you like to see each week ‚Äòthemed‚Äô by topic, or would you prefer a mix of fields each week?

As always, if you get value out of this, I‚Äôd appreciate you sharing it or my Twitter profile on Twitter so others can get value out of it too :)

item.title: North Star Metric, Calendar-Priority Alignment, Pre-suasion, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 11 mental models that will help you achieve more

North Star Metric

In a company, a north-star is the one metric that the company optimizes for over all others.

It‚Äôs the metric that produces the most business value over the long term when optimized.

For example, Airbnb's north-star metric is ‚Äú# of nights booked.‚Äù

item.title: Others' reactions to you reveal their relationship with themselves
item.description:
‚ÄçOthers' reactions to you reveal their relationship with themselves, not your worth.

People's behavior rarely has anything to do with you. It's projection. A mirror of their inner world. Most take it personally anyway. When someone lashes out, we instinctively believe we caused it. We didn't. Their reaction comes from somewhere else entirely. Some unresolved pain. Some private battle you know nothing about.

The moment you see others' behavior as their own internal struggle externalized, you gain freedom.

item.title: Parables & Short Stories
Paul Graham on Wealth Creation, Living a Fulfilling Life, and Beating The Status Quo
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 16 Powerful Mental Models from Paul Graham on wealth creation, living a fulfilling life, and beating the status quo

Paul Graham is one of the most influential technologists in the world.

He‚Äôs also written 200+ essays since 1993 that are a gold mine of wisdom on wealth creation, living a fulfilling life, and beating the status quo.

item.title: Personal Growth
Preparation kills anxiety
item.description: I‚Äôm sweating profusely in fear and anxiety. It‚Äôs June 2015, I‚Äôm sitting in an exam room‚Äîthe classic gymnasium filled with plastic chairs and wooden desks wall-to-wall, shoulder to shoulder.  It's my intro to Finance exam, notoriously difficult. It‚Äôs only 15 minutes in but it feels like it‚Äôs been an hour. I can't focus. It feels like time is standing still. Thoughts rush through my mind: "There's no way I'm going to pass this. If I don't, I might fail the unit, and it's going to be a blemish on my record forever. Why is this exam so hard?‚Äù

item.title: Pro/Con Lists - A Framework for Effective Decision Making
item.description:
For many people, Pro/Con lists are the go-to decision-making tool for most decisions:

  • Where to live?
  • Where to work?
  • Where to study?

They involve listing all the positive things about a certain decision (the pros) and comparing them against the negative things (the cons).

While useful in extremely simple cases, Pro/Con lists have big shortcomings:

1/ They cause you to overlook the cons

2/ They don't assign weights to the items

3/ They assume there are only two options

item.title: Problem Solving: Find The Root Cause, The Minto Pyramid Principle, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 500(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This week: 5 of the best problem solving methods I've found

1) Find The Root Cause

A proximate cause is the most immediately observable cause of a problem.

The symptom.

The root cause is the underlying reason.

The disease.

When problem solving, find the root cause to ensure it doesn't happen again.

How? The 5 Whys Method

item.title: Problems worth thinking about
item.description:
Agriculture

‚Äç

Feeding 10 billion people by 2050 is a huge challenge (food)

Feeding 10 billion people by 2050 is a monumental challenge. We need to produce more food in the next 30 years than in all of human history. This requires a shift in how we grow food, as arable land is decreasing due to erosion‚Äîover half has likely been lost since agriculture began. Fossil fuel dependence for fertilizers poses another risk, highlighted by soaring food prices after the Ukraine crisis.

item.title: Systems I use
item.description:
‚ÄçPhysical & mental health

‚Äç

Exercise

  • 1x daily morning walk 20 mins (heart rate optimisation during the walk between ‚Äî 100-120 BPM (median heart rate)‚Äç
  • 4x weight sessions upper/lower body + 1x HIIT session
  • Work with personal trainer for accountability+better results‚Äç

‚Äç

Diet

  • Slow Carb Diet‚Äç
  • Avoid sugars/heavy carb meals
  • Avoid alcohol
  • Athletic greens 1x daily
  • Intermittent supplements incl. Nootropics
  • Fasting. 2x/month - 2 days. 4x/year - 4 days

‚Äç

Sleep

  • 7.5 hours of sleep per night
  • Eight Sleep for sleeping comfort
  • Melatonin for getting back in sleep rhythm and/or adjusting to timezones

‚Äç

item.title: The Business Dad Paradox, Miles‚Äôs Law, Deliberate Ignorance, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 455(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 7 powerful mental models for better thinking

The Business Dad Paradox

Technology has allowed us to become more efficient in our work.

Increased efficiency means more of the most precious commodity: time.

But time for what, exactly? Usually, to do more work.

h/t @annehelen & @cwarzel

Miles‚Äôs Law

‚ÄùWhere you stand depends on where you sit.‚Äù

item.title: The Crow and the Pitcher by Aesop
item.description:
‚ÄúOn a hot summer day, a thirsty crow flew around searching for water. It had been a long day, and the crow was growing increasingly desperate. Finally, it came across a pitcher with a small amount of water at the bottom.

The crow tried to reach the water, but the pitcher was too deep and its neck too narrow for the crow to fit its beak inside.Feeling disheartened, the crow could have given up and continued searching for water elsewhere.

item.title: The Dog And His Reflection by Aesop
item.description:
‚ÄúA Dog, to whom the butcher had thrown a bone, was hurrying home with his prize as fast as he could go. As he crossed a narrow footbridge, he happened to look down and saw himself reflected in the quiet water as if in a mirror. But the greedy Dog thought he saw a real Dog carrying a bone much bigger than his own.

If he had stopped to think he would have known better. But instead of thinking, he dropped his bone and sprang at the Dog in the river, only to find himself swimming for dear life to reach the shore. At last he managed to scramble out, and as he stood sadly thinking about the good bone he had lost, he realized what a stupid Dog he had been.

item.title: The fastest learners are unburdened by embarrassment
item.description:
‚ÄçThe fastest learners are unburdened by embarrassment.

Think about the last time you were learning something new ‚Äî a language, a sport, or a skill. Did you hold back from asking questions or practicing in front of others out of fear of looking foolish? Most do.

As Thomas Newkirk put it:
"Embarrassment is a true enemy of learning."
It blocks full engagement with the learning process. It stops us from making the mistakes that growth demands.

item.title: The fruits of reading
item.description:
Knowledge acquisition is a gross underestimation of the fruits of reading.

There is a saying, ‚ÄúKill two birds with one stone.‚Äù

Reading is closer to ‚ÄúKill a flock with a rock.‚Äù

A non-exhaustive list of the benefits of reading:

  • Find inspiration
  • Heightened empathy
  • Broadened vocabulary
  • Knowledge acquisition
  • Solve others‚Äô problems
  • Prevent others‚Äô mistakes
  • Prevent your own mistakes
  • Improved written communication
  • Improved verbal communication
  • Solve your own problems more efficiently
  • Cultivate the habit of sustained attention
  • Increased creativity by allowing you to combine ideas
  • Meditation-like benefits of quietening the monkey mind
  • Add depth and meaning to everyday interactions with more raw material
  • A greater capacity for meaningful interactions with a wider range of people

When you‚Äôre justifying reading more, remember that it‚Äôs not just knowledge acquisition.

item.title: The high-return activity of raising others‚Äô aspirations
item.description:
I was coached by an eight-time Olympian. A lesson he taught me will stick with me for life. In 2011, I was 3 years into my junior water polo career.

‚Äç

I'd been playing for the Dolphins when the coach of a competitor club and 8-time Australian Olympian, Tom Hoad, asked me to join his team and travel to Europe that Winter. Little did I know that this was the first step in one of the most rewarding adventures of my teens‚Äîand an introduction to an idea that will stick with me for life.

item.title: The Inside-Outside View, Ladder of Inference, Confidence Determines Speed vs. Quality, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 213(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This week: 15 of the best decision-making mental models I've found

1) The Inside-Outside View

We have a natural tendency to favour the inside view‚Äîour own independent solution to a problem that incorporates all of our hidden biases.

To make better decisions, we should favour the outside view‚Äîone that incorporates the best available data.

item.title: The Jeff Bezos Reversible vs. Irreversible Decisions Framework
item.description:
Welcome to the 500(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This week: The Jeff Bezos Reversible vs. Irreversible Decisions Framework

The Jeff Bezos Reversible vs. Irreversible Decisions Framework is a powerful mental model for unlocking growth in your career, business, relationships, or life.

In this newsletter, we'll cover what it is and how you can use it to improve your life.

item.title: The Paradox of Unanimity, The Great Temptation, Centrality, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 9 mental models for better thinking

The Paradox of Unanimity

Under ancient Jewish law, if a suspect was found guilty by all judges, they were acquitted.

Too much agreement implies a systematic error in judgment.

Beware of unanimous agreement, it might mean a bad decision‚Ä¶

The Great Temptation

We haven‚Äôt found aliens yet, so what if extraterrestrial intelligence has a deep tendency to be self-limiting or even self-exterminating?

item.title: The Productivity Frontier, Flow States, Write Before Action, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 7 of the most powerful concepts for having your most successful year yet

The Productivity Frontier

Up to a point‚Äîthe productivity frontier‚Äîproductivity is about optimizing the way you work.

When you reach the frontier, higher achievement results from making hard trade-offs about what you work on.

Focus and single-tasking are key.

item.title: The Psychology Of Money ‚Äî 20 Quotes Psychology, Building Wealth, And Happiness
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: The Psychology of Money ‚Äî 20 quotes psychology, building wealth, and happiness

The Psychology of Money by Morgan Housel is the best money book I've ever read.

Hidden inside this gem is a mini-degree in psychology, building wealth, and happiness.

Here are 20 quotes that will change the way you think about money:

1/

"You might think you want an expensive car, a fancy watch, and a huge house.

What you want is respect and admiration from other people, and you think having expensive stuff will bring it.

It almost never does‚Äîespecially from the people you want to respect and admire you.‚Äù

item.title: The Rule of Three, Morphological Analysis, Mind Reading Illusion, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the 346(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: Mental models that will make you smarter

The Rule of Three

‚ÄùWhenever you‚Äôre trying to persuade a person to do something, always present 3 reasons. Not 2, not 4, but exactly 3.‚Äù

It gets people‚Äôs attention and most of us have been hard-wired to expect things in groups of 3‚Äîso it‚Äôs more persuasive.

item.title: The Tony Marsh Method, Checklists, Table Selection & More
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the A Players newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 8 mental models for better thinking

The Tony Marsh Method

When trying to remember something, encode the memory as closely as possible to the environment in which it will be retrieved.

If you want to learn French, don‚Äôt spend time in the classroom, speak to native speakers in France.

Your memory will improve.

item.title: The whole world is insecure
item.description:
The aroma of bacon and coffee wafts through the air, a stark contrast to the weighty conversations unfolding around me. It‚Äôs July 2024, I‚Äôm sitting in a large conference room with endless round tables eating a hot breakfast alongside mediocre, hotel-calibre coffee.

‚Äç

Sitting next to me is a ~40 year-old man named Toby. Toby sold his business for over $400m three years ago. I‚Äôm sharing my experience building a social media audience, what it was like getting started, and how it‚Äôs changed my life.

item.title: The World-Class Framework for Getting Luckier ‚Äî From The Most Powerful Woman In Startups
item.description:
Welcome to the 300(!) new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: The World-Class Framework ‚Äî How the most powerful woman in startups created the ‚Äòluck‚Äô that launched her career

Ann Miura-Ko (@annimaniac) has been labeled the most powerful woman in start-ups by Forbes.

She is:

  • A co-founding partner of Floodgate Venture Capital
  • An early investor and board member in Lyft
  • A lecturer in entrepreneurship at Stanford
  • And a world-class debater

Ann‚Äôs parents came to America seeking opportunity having grown up in post-WW2 Japan.

item.title: Tilt, Do/Say Something Syndrome, Availability Bias, & More
item.description:
Hello Mental Models Lovers!

It's great to have you on board for the first edition of my weekly newsletter‚ÄîI appreciate your early support.

This week was a truncated one, meaning 62 models were covered.

I'll be looking to share ~100/week on average over the next ~15 weeks‚Äî that's a lot of mental models.

So without further ado, let's get into it! This week focused on psychological biases and general thinking concepts.

As you read through, I would love if you could consider the following questions (please shoot me a response if you'd like to give feedback on either of them!):

item.title: Tim C.
item.description: I just wanted to reach out and say thank you for the content you post. Your content is extremely useful and relevant to me. I see a lot of content but yours is by far the best.

item.title: TL;DV, Bardeen AI, Sunsama, & More
item.description:

Bardeen AI

item.title: We judge ourselves by what we know we‚Äôre capable of
item.description:
The clink of silverware against plates suddenly stops, replaced by a stunned silence that surrounds the table. Heads turn, eyes widen, and the woman next to me nearly chokes on her coffee, her hand frozen midway to her mouth. It‚Äôs July 2024 and I‚Äôm sitting in a conference room in Victoria, Canada, eating a hot breakfast.

‚Äç

On my left is a ~40 year-old man named Toby who sold his business for $400m three years ago. I can‚Äôt believe the words that have just come out of his mouth. It feels like I‚Äôm in a movie. Is this guy a comedian? I lean in with intrigue, thinking that he‚Äôs about to tell me he‚Äôs joking. I wonder what he‚Äôs going to say next.

item.title: What I learned at Goldman Sachs
item.description:
1. High agency

High-agency people happen to the world; the world doesn‚Äôt happen to them. They take ultimate responsibility and see everything as a problem to be solved with creative solutions. If they haven‚Äôt solved a problem before, they speak to someone who has or find an answer. They never ask, ‚ÄúHow do I do this?‚Äù without first trying to answer that themselves.

‚Äç

2. High-speed communication‚Äç

Let‚Äôs be real: Communication is a core part of any role. Those who respond quickly are people we consider to have their ‚Äúsh*t‚Äù together. This is no different in the workplace. Speed demonstrates attentiveness and conscientiousness‚Äîtwo critical predictors of success.

item.title: What trait do 9/10 billionaires credit for their success?
item.description:
What trait do 9/10 billionaires credit for their success? ‚ÄúAgency‚Äù Here‚Äôs what it is and how you can develop it‚Ä¶

Agency is influencing the external environment to shape it in your favour. It‚Äôs moving from passive receiver of circumstances to active shaper of reality. It‚Äôs rejecting the world's status quo and making a new world instead. It‚Äôs removing the word ‚ÄúNo‚Äù from your vocabulary.

‚Äç

It‚Äôs acting on impulses that hide behind shadows of fear, doubt, and comparison. It‚Äôs noticing something that isn‚Äôt right and having the courage to make it so. It‚Äôs changing history by sheer force of will. Agentic people happen to the world; the world doesn‚Äôt happen to them.

item.title: Wrong-Side-of-Maybe Fallacy, Load Theory, Luxury Beliefs, & More
item.description:
Welcome to the new friends of the A Players newsletter who have joined us since last week!

This Week: 8 of the most interesting ideas I've found

Wrong-Side-of-Maybe Fallacy

People judge the same way: they look at which side of ‚Äúmaybe‚Äù‚Äî50%‚Äîthe probability was on.

If the forecast said there was a 70% chance of rain and it rains, people think the forecast was right; if it doesn‚Äôt rain, they think it was wrong.
